Hi. I cannot answer your question directly, but for whatever its
failings might or might not be, I understand that the photographs in the
1st were taken from fittings actually seen rather than being photographs
of photographs as is common. I am sure that the highest value added
would be  from the 1st and translation, along with a list of the gimei
if known. Arnold 

>>> craigharris@... 02/25/05 11:34 PM >>>

I have a question from a customer about the editions of the Kinko
Meikan.
The original edition published in 1974 has four mei photos per page, and
there is a wonderfully handy translation published by the NCJSC that was
done by John Yumoto and Alan Harvie, which is still available from the
club.
 
Obviously the translation makes this edition far more desirable to
non-readers of Japanese than the later edition(s) which show six mei
photos
per page, and of course do not match up with the translation at all.
 
My question has to do with my recollection - it was perhaps even a
discussion on one of the lists long ago - that the problem with the
first
edition was the significant number of gimei signatures illustrated, and
perhaps other errors. These were then corrected in the later editions.
 
I've searched what archives I have to verify this bit of information
kicking
around my aging and untrustworthy brain without success. Can anyone
corroborate or refute this or shed any light on the subject?
 
And before anyone asks, I'm out of stock on the first edition, but you
can
add your name to the want list. Second edition orders will be filled
right
away!
 
 
Craig L. Harris                                             Bridge of
